Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

CIF: Small: Fast In Vivo Optical Imaging in the Heavily and Weakly Scattering Regimes

Kevin Webb, Purdue University


Optical imaging is important in medicine because it provides unique information about human health and an avenue for inexpensive and portable instruments for laboratory, clinical and home use. Within a deep-tissue optical diffusion tomography framework, it becomes possible to determine chemical and molecular information for blood chemistry monitoring and understanding diseases. The research on faster and more accurate deep-tissue imaging is a critical step in facilitating more widespread use of optics in medical research and for treatment. Another important challenge for in vivo optical imaging is access to the regime within a few millimeters of the skin, with application to skin cancer, for example. This research involves the development of a method that describes optical tissue properties on this near-surface length scale and hence provides a basis for imaging. Collectively, this work will be important in applications like the early detection of cancer, intra-operative imaging to ensure all tumor nodules are removed during surgery, and blood chemistry monitoring.

More specifically, various optical diffusion tomography modalities describing scatter and absorption, fluorescence, and fluorescence resonance energy transfer parameters are being developed. The approach avoids a background scattering emulsion, in which the subject is placed, by use of a laser body scan to define the geometry and an unstructured mesh forward model based on the diffusion equation. In this work, a multigrid method coupled to the unstructured mesh permits fast and accurate imaging. In the weakly scattering regime, an imaging method based on the Bethe-Salpeter equation that uses a rigorous field correlation over space and frequency is being developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The focus of this project was the development of fast and accurate deep tissue in vivo optical imaging techniques, with a view to opening new in vivo research avenues and ultimately clinical applications. The use of light provides fundamental information through spectroscopy, and also the opportunity for safe, inexpensive, and portable instruments. However, the ability to image in deep tissue has been hindered by the degree of optical scatter, which motivates the new imaging approaches investigated during this project. The major research accomplishments were as follows.

Multigrid for optical diffusion tomography: In the heavily scattering regime, a diffusion equation representation for modulated light in tissue may be used, and when coupled with an optimization-based imaging method, three-dimensional spatial images of scatter and absorption can be formed by a method known as optical diffusion tomography. We extended our multigrid inversion scheme, where multiple spatial resolutions are used to aid the reconstruction, to allow the reconstruction of objects of arbitrary shape with no background scattering emulsion by facilitating the mapping between finite element method meshes and Cartesian grids. The algorithm was applied to experimental data to form images of a mouse liver from in vivo measurement data.

Animal phantoms for the development of optical imaging: We realized a new type of tissue phantom using rapid prototyping and 3D printing, to allow for the development of imaging methods and the calibration of data from subjects. The approach allows for the detailed design of the phantom geometry and the placement of complex inhomogeneities using multiple materials.  We showed it is possible to image deep in these animal phantoms using optical diffusion tomography. 

In vivo mouse imaging and kinetics: Use of fluorescence allows enhanced contrast and specificity through fluorescence optical diffusion tomography. We showed an injected fluorophore could be attached to cancer cells to provide a contrast mechanism for deep tissue imaging. A new experimental setup allowed data to be captured in vivo by continuously delivering anesthesia to the mouse. Absorption and fluorescence images of a mouse tumor were achieved, providing information about the delivery of an anticancer drug. Equations describing the kinetics of this process were solved within an optimization framework, allowing the release rate to be determined for the first time. This work will aid in the development of anticancer drugs by using the optical imaging method as a way to characterize the targeting and release process when the drug is used in test animals.

Improved optimization-based imaging: We introduced a dynamic threshold method that incorporated a noise reduction step into the iterative reconstruction method to improve the reconstructed image quality. The approach was tested on a terahertz-imaging problem, an extension of our computational imaging work.

Bethe-Salpeter equation model in the non-diffusive regime: In the important regime where the traditional diffusion model does not hold, another description of the scattering medium is required. Imaging in this regime is possible using the Bethe-Salpeter equation, which describes the measurement data through a field correlation over space and frequency. We showed that the scalar Bethe-Salpeter equation solution captures the necessary information about the scattering medium when considering the same polarization as that incident. This work should facilitate deep tissue imaging where there is less scatter than that described by a diffusion picture.

Localization for improved resolution: We invoked localization as a means to improve the spatial and resolution of diffusive imaging. The approach we considered assumed that each fluorophore fires with a different delay, as would be the case for fluorescent tags in the brain. Each fluorophore is then localized individually, and a high-resolution image can thus be formed. We also showed experimental validation of the localization of a fluorescent point source in a slab and determined the super resolution attributes. These experimental results establish that the localization accuracy can be in the range of tens of microns through centimeters of tissue.

Broader Impacts:

Two people involved in this project completed their Ph.D. degrees, and two others who were supported in part made important contributions and will complete their Ph.D. degrees under other funding. During the course of this work, the graduate students involved participated in campus events to introduce science to students in grades K-12 and at the college level. These events included attending a high school in northwest Indiana to promote engineering and answer questions about being a Purdue engineering student, presenting posters on current projects to prospective graduate students during the Purdue ECE open house, participating in the West Lafayette, Indiana Happy Hollow School tour at Purdue, targeted towards middle school students who spend a day on campus learning about engineering, and participating in the Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day sponsored by Purdue's Women in Engineering Program, where freshmen and sophomores in high school from across the Midwest spend the day on campus learning about engineering.
